item.title: The Two New Tensions at the Federal Reserve
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 18, 2025. Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged and continued to pencil in two rate cuts in 2025, saying uncertainty over the economic outlook was still high but had diminished. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: The US Has More Copper Than China But No Way to Refine All of It
item.description: The industry will need to overcome high energy and labor costs, environmental regulations and a glut of cheap Chinese competition to make US copper smelting great again.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lorinc, James Attwood, Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: Vessels and residual ore at the idled Asarco smelter in Hayden, Arizona.

item.title: Trump Pledge of Quick China Magnet Flows Has Yet to Materialize
item.description: Almost 10 days since President Donald Trump declared a “done” trade deal with Beijing, US companies remain largely in the dark on when they’ll receive crucial magnets from China — and whether Washington, in turn, will allow a host of other exports to resume.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Mackenzie Hawkins, Joe Deaux, Gabrielle Coppola

media:content.media:description: NdFeB alloy strip at the Australia Strategic Materials Ltd.'s Korean Metals Plant, in the Ochang Foreign Investment Zone, in Cheongju, South Korea, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025. Australian Strategic Materials Ltd. produces alloys for magnets at a plant in South Korea. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Waller Says Fed Could Cut Interest Rates as Soon as July
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said the central bank can lower interest rates as soon as next month, reiterating his view that the inflation hit from tariffs is likely to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Governor of the US Federal Reserve Christopher Waller

item.title: Canada Retail Sales Fell 1.1% in May, Largest Drop in a Year
item.description: The strain on Canadian consumers became more evident last month after a rush to buy cars ahead of price increases from tariffs appeared to come to an end.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: An auto dealership in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada, in March. Photographer: Artur Widak/NurPhoto/Getty Images

item.title: Thousands of Laid-Off Government Workers Are Flooding a Shrinking Job Market
item.description: Thousands of private government consultants laid off during the Trump administration’s cost-cutting crusade are increasingly flooding a shrinking labor market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Phua

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, on Feb. 25.

item.title: RBI Front-Loaded Rate Action to Spur Demand, Minutes Show
item.description: India’s rate-setters opted for a larger-than-expected interest rate cut to spur demand, while adjusting the policy stance to retain flexibility amid global uncertainty, minutes of the central bank’s policy meeting showed Friday.
item.dc:creator: Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: Sanjay Malhotra, governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), during a news conference in Mumbai, India, on Friday, June 6, 2025. India's central bank cut interest rates more than projected and unexpectedly reduced the cash reserve ratio for banks, providing a major liquidity boost to the economy as growth prospects dim and inflation subsides.

item.title: Banks Offer Higher Rates on Deposits as BOE Drains Liquidity
item.description: UK banks are offering unusually high interest rates to clients in order to attract cash, the latest sign of how the Bank of England’s balance-sheet reduction is shrinking liquidity in the system.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie

item.title: Plunging UK Retail Sales Deepen Concern About Broader Slowdown
item.description: A dramatic drop in UK retail sales is raising fresh questions about the sustainability of Britain’s recent growth spurt and Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s plans to use it to restore controversial benefit cuts.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: A shopper at a supermarket in London. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Thriving Southern Cities Face Economic Threat From Funding Cuts
item.description: North Carolina's Research Triangle shows how federal efforts to curb spending are unleashing economic uncertainty in communities across the US.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva, Amara Omeokwe, Amanda Albright

media:content.media:description: Chapel Hill, N.C. - June 17th, 2025: The University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill has also been impacted by federal funding cuts. (Cornell Watson for Bloomberg News)

item.title: China Shrugs Off Tariffs But Not its Property Slump
item.description: I’m Malcolm Scott, international economics editor in Sydney. Today we’re looking at China’s property drag. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott

item.title: Japan Surprises With Bigger Cut to Super-Long Bond Issuance
item.description: Japan is planning to cut the issuance of super-long bonds this year by more than earlier reported as it tries to restore calm to a market spooked by recent record highs in yields.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Mia Glass

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian walks past the Ministry of Finance building in Tokyo.

item.title: Political Woes Could Sink Thai Economy Deeper Into Malaise
item.description: Thailand’s sudden descent into a new political crisis threatens an economy that’s already on the brink of a technical recession and bracing for the impact of the global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra at a news conference in Bangkok on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: BOE’s Bailey Raises Doubts Over Digital Pound for Consumers
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey cast doubt on the need for a digital pound for consumers, calling into question whether the UK will push ahead with its plans.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey Photographer: Darren Staples/Bloomberg

item.title: A Guide to Trade Talks, Trump-Style: Is His Unorthodox Approach Working?
item.description: The president is trying force rather than persuasion to secure improved access to foreign markets for US companies. The quick wins he promised are yet to materialize.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard

item.title: Zichen Wang's Exit Interview From America
item.description: The popular Substacker returns home to China.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: US and Chinese flags in the entrance during trade talks at Lancaster House in London, UK, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025. Talks between the US and China extended later into their second day in London, with financial markets on edge as the world’s largest economies negotiate over key tech and industrial exports and deescalating their trade war. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Odd Lots: Zichen Wang’s Exit Interview from America (Podcast)
item.description: Zichen Wang is the writer of the Pekingnology newsletter, which translates important speeches and articles from China into English, and contextualizes them for Western readers. Over the past year, he’s been a master’s degree student at Princeton University, although he’s recently returned home to resume his career at a think tank in China. His stint in the US obviously came at a very interesting time, both due to the rising US-China tensions, and also the growing restrictions on Chinese students
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Japan’s Prices Climb by Most in Two Years Ahead of Election
item.description: Japan’s key consumer inflation measure accelerated more than expected to a fresh two-year high, as Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba gears up for a summer election and the Bank of Japan mulls the country’s price trajectory.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: Japan Won’t Fixate on July 9 in US Trade Talks, Akazawa Says
item.description: Japan won’t fixate on the looming date for so-called reciprocal tariffs to go back to higher levels, Tokyo’s top trade negotiator said, signaling that the Asian nation stands ready for the possibility that talks will drag on.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: French Manufacturing Confidence Unexpectedly Dips in June
item.description: French manufacturing confidence fell unexpectedly in June, adding to warning signs for an economy already struggling to keep pace with European peers.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Employees work on a tramway production line in Bagneres-de-Bigorre, France.

item.title: UK Budget Deficit Running Below Forecast in Boost for Reeves
item.description: UK government borrowing came in below forecast in the first two months of the fiscal year, a modest boost for Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves as she faces growing questions over whether she can keep to her budget limits without further tax and spending pain.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Atkinson, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves Photographer: Jonathan Brady/Getty Images

item.title: US Tariff Spike Hits China’s Small Parcels, Squeezing Exporters
item.description: US tariff hikes on small packages from China triggered a slump in shipments last month, contributing to a huge drop in bilateral trade and roiling exporters like Shein Group Ltd.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Daniela Wei

item.title: Fidelity Fund Bets on Midcaps Saying Tariff Shock Is Over
item.description: Financial markets have seen the worst of Donald Trump’s tariff threats, helping make midcap stocks an attractive buy as the outlook improves, according to a Fidelity International money manager.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson

item.title: South Korea’s Record Surplus With US Adds Strain to Tariff Talks
item.description: South Korea’s current account surplus with the US surged to a record high last year, highlighting the challenge President Lee Jae Myung faces as he seeks to secure a trade deal with Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: Hyundai Motor vehicles loaded onto a cargo ship at a port in Ulsan, South Korea. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan to Sound Out Market Players on Tweaks to Bond Issuance
item.description: Japan’s Finance Ministry will seek feedback from market players later Friday over its planned reductions to super-long bond issuance as it takes steps to quell market turbulence.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Hidenori Yamanaka

media:content.media:description: Tokyo station and commercial buildings at night in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2024. Traders betting on further recovery in Japanese equities are looking to any steer from the Bank of Japan that may cap the yen’s gains and support exporters.

item.title: UK Consumer Confidence Rises, Extending a ‘Fragile’ Rebound
item.description: The confidence of UK consumers improved for a second straight month, a survey found, extending a rebound that’s at risk of being derailed as war in the Middle East and higher oil prices cloud the economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: Xi’s Giant Iron Ore Trader Is Shaking Up a $130 Billion Market
item.description: Just three years after its founding, a Chinese government-run trader has become the single biggest force in the country’s $130 billion market for iron ore imports.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell, Alfred Cang

media:content.media:description: QINGDAO, CHINA - MAY 07 2025: Machines work on a dock for imported iron ore in Qingdao in east China's Shandong province Wednesday, May 07, 2025. (Photo credit should read YU FANGPING / Feature China/Future Publishing via Getty Images)

item.title: Employees Terrified of ICE Raids Are Failing to Show Up at Work
item.description: High-profile immigration raids are scaring off workers and leaving employers unsure of how they’ll manage without them.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Maxwell Adler, Michael Smith

media:content.media:description: Farmworkers harvest Brussels sprouts at a farm in Oxnard, California, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025.

item.title: EU’s Dombrovskis Says ‘Making Progress’ in Trade Talks With US
item.description: The European Union is continuing intensive trade talks with the US ahead of a July 9 tariff deadline set by President Donald Trump and is “making progress,” according to EU Economy Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Valdis Dombrovskis, economy commissioner for the European Union (EU), during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Luxembourg, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. The Eurogroup is about to kick off its search for a new president, with Paschal Donohoeseen on track to win a third term, a feat that would make the Irishman the second-longest-serving chair of the euro zones finance-chief meetings.

item.title: Maduro Locks Up Economists Sharing Data on Venezuela’s Decline
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro has intensified his crackdown on independent economists and consultants, detaining at least eight people in what critics call a bid to control data exposing Venezuela’s decline.
item.dc:creator: Andreina Itriago, Patricia Laya

media:content.media:description: A man passes a foreign-exchange themed mural in Caracas on June 2. The widening gap between the official and black-market rates threatens to fuel inflation.
